Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|お盆|お盆 (Obon)}} [[File:Mukaebi_20120731.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|盆}}: [[Obon]]. Lighting the welcome [[beacon]]s in [[w:Numazu,_Shizuoka|Numazu]], [[w:Shizuoka_Prefecture|Shizuoka Prefecture]].]] {{wikipedia|Bon Festival}}
{{ja-kanjitab|ぼん|yomi=o}} Short for {{m|ja|盂蘭盆|tr=Urabon}} or {{m|ja|盂蘭盆会|tr=Urabon'e}}, from {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=ほん'}} {{m|ltc|盂蘭盆|tr=hju lan bwon}} or {{m|ltc|盂蘭盆會|tr=hju lan bwon hwajH}} (compare modern {{cog|cmn|盂蘭盆|tr=yúlánpén}} or {{zh-l|盂蘭盆會|tr=yúlánpénhuì}}), a transcription of {{der|ja|pi|sort=ほん'|ullumpana||raising, helping}}, [[present participle]] of {{cog|pi|-}} verb {{m|pi|ullumpati||to raise up, to help}}. A number of Japanese dictionaries state that this term derives from {{cog|sa|उल्लम्बन}}, purportedly meaning “hanging upside-down” in reference to the souls of the dead being tortured in hell by being strung up by their feet.{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}{{R:Daijirin}}{{R:Daijisen}}{{R:Shinmeikai5}} However, the {{cog|sa|-}} word would be the [[present participle]] of verb {{m|sa|उल्लम्ब्||to hang|pos=intransitive}}, with no inherent “upside-down” meaning.[http://spokensanskrit.org/index.php?tran_input=ullamb ''ullamb''-related entries at SpokenSanskrit.org website][http://sanskritdictionary.com/ullamb/42749/1 ''ullamb'' entry at Sanskrit Dictionary website] Moreover, neither the purported meaning of “hanging upside-down” nor the verifiable meaning of “hanging” match very well, given that the ''urabon'' ceremonies are about helping the dead, closer in meaning to the “helping” sense of the {{cog|pi|-}} verb.[https://dsalsrv04.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/app/pali_query.py?qs=Ullumpana&searchhws=yes ''ulllumpana'' entry at The Pali Text Society's Pali-English Dictionary website] This suggests that explanations of the dead hanging upside-down in hell are more likely to be [[folk etymologies]] based on a mistaken connection to the {{cog|sa|-}} verb, rather than a more direct semantic link to the {{cog|pi|-}}. {{rfv-etymology|ja}}

subSections.title: Derived terms
Idioms
subSections.text:
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-r|盆と正月が一緒に来たよう|^ぼん と ^しょうがつ が いっしょ に きた よう}}: “as if Bon and New Years came together” → extremely busy; an overlap of multiple happy occasions
* {{ja-r|盆と正月が一時に来たよう|^ぼん と ^しょうがつ が いっとき に きた よう}}: “as if Bon and New Years came at the same time” → extremely busy; an overlap of multiple happy occasions
* {{ja-r|盆の十六日は地獄の釜の蓋が開く|^ぼん の じゅうろく-にち は じごく の かま の ふた が あく}}: “on the 16th day of Bon, the lids on the kettles of hell open up” → from a tradition that the 16th day of July (the day just after Obon) is a day of rest and relative peace for the souls of the damned, when the demons of hell temporarily let people off the hook, and employers in this world would give their employees a day off
* {{ja-r|盆過ぎての鯖商い|^ぼん すぎて の さば あきない}}: “the mackerel business after Bon has finished” → a metaphor for something past its [[prime]], from the way that grilled mackerel was often given as a gift food item or as an [[offering]] during [[Obon]]
* {{ja-r|盆過ぎての蓮の葉|^ぼん すぎて の はす の .は}}: “a [[lotus]] leaf after Bon has finished” → a metaphor for something past its [[prime]], from the way that lotus leaves would often be used in [[offering]]s during [[Obon]]
* {{ja-r|盆過ぎての蓮の花|^ぼん すぎて の はす の はな}}: “a [[lotus]] blossom after Bon has finished” → a metaphor for something past its [[prime]], from the way that lotus flowers would often be used in [[offering]]s during [[Obon]]
* {{ja-r|盆三日は嫁と姑が仲よくなる|^ぼん みっか は よめ と しゅうとめ が なかよく なる}}: “brides and mothers-in-law (can) get along for the three days of Bon” → from how family and other guests come to visit during [[Obon]]; compare the famous {{w|Benjamin Franklin}} quote, “After three days men grow weary of a wench, a guest, and weather rainy.”
{{der-bottom}}
